article.title: OVal - object validation framework for Java 5

section.title: What is OVal?
section.para: OVal is a generic validation frameworks for any kind of Java objects (not only JavaBeans) and allows you:

listitem.para: to specify constraints for class fields and method return values
to easily validate objects on demand
to specify constraints for constructor parameters that are automatically checked when the constructor is called
to specify constraints for method parameters that are automatically checked when the method is called
to enforce full object validation after an object instance has been created
to enforce full object validation before a method of the object is called
to enforce full object validation after a method of the object is called
to either let OVal throw constraint violation exceptions during automatic checks or alternatively notify constraint violation listeners.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: OVal requires Java 5 and AspectJ. Java 5 is required for annotation support. AspectJ is used to support programming by contract (e.g. to enforce constraints for constructor and method parameters).
If you are only interested in validating objects based on specified field constraints AspectJ is not required.

section.title: Specifying constraints for class fields
section.para: You can add constraint annotations to class fields that are checked when an object validation is performed. An object can be validated by using the public static validate(Object validatedObject) method of net.sf.oval.Validator

section.title: Specifying constraints for getter method return value
section.para: Additionally to field constraints you can also specify constraints for the return value of getter methods. When validating the object the values of all fields and the return values of the getter methods are checked against the specified constraints.

Following the JavaBeans specification (http://java.sun.com/products/javabeans/index.jsp) OVal identifies parameterless non-void methods whose names start with "is" (e.g. public boolean isEnabled() ) or "get" (e.g. public String getName()) as getter methods. Return value constraints specified for other method types are ignored during validation.

Important: To retrieve the return value of the getter method it is invoked by the Validator. Therefore ensure that your getter method really is just a getter method and doesn't change the object state.

section.title: Using OVal for programming by contract
section.para: By utilizing AspectJ OVal provides support for several aspects of programming by contract, but is not a full blown programming by contract implementation.
With OVal you can

listitem.para: allow the execution of a class constructor or method only if the passed parameters satisfy prior defined constraints (pre condition)
allow the execution of a method only if the object is in a certain state (pre condition)
enforce that the return value of a method must satisfy prior defined constraints (post condition)
enforce the object must be in a certain state after a method has been executed (post condition)

section.title: Preparing your project
section.para: The easiest way to get started is to use the Eclipse IDE in conjunction with the AspectJ plug-in.
Create a new AspectJ project or add AspectJ support to an existing Java project by right-clicking the project in the Package Explorer and selecting Convert To AspectJ Project
Add the net.sf.oval.jar file to your libary path.

Create a new aspect via File -> New -> Aspect that extends the abstract aspect net.sf.oval.ValidationAspect. When the new aspect is created the AspectJ builder will automatically weave the programming-by-contract related code into your classes annotated with @net.sf.oval.annotations.Constrained when they get compiled.
Now you can create all your business classes, add the @net.sf.oval.annotations.Constrained annotation and define the required constraints using the built-in or custom constraint annotations.

section.title: Specifying constraints for constructor parameters (pre condition)
section.para: Constraints specified for constructor parameters are automatically checked when the constructor is called. A call to the constructor is prohibited if any of the constraints is not satisfied.
Example usage:
section.programlisting: BusinessObject bo = new BusinessObject(null); // throws a ConstraintsViolatedException because parameter name is null

section.title: Specifying constraints for method parameters (pre condition)
section.para: Constraints specified for method parameters are automatically checked when the method is called.A call to the method is prohibited if any of the constraints is not satisfied.
Example usage:
section.programlisting: BusinessObject bo = new BusinessObject(); bo.setName(null); // throws a ConstraintsViolatedException because parameter name is null

section.title: Applying field constraints to constructor/method parameters (pre condition)
section.para: You can apply the constraints specified for a field to any constructor or method parameter in the same class by using the @net.sf.oval.annotations.FieldConstraints annotation.

If you do not specify a field name within the @net.sf.oval.annotations.FieldConstraints annotation the constraints of the field with the same name as the annotated parameter are applied to the parameter.
If you specify a field name within the @net.sf.oval.annotations.FieldConstraints annotation the constraints of the field with the specified name are applied to the annotated parameter.
Example usage:

section.title: Enforcing full object validation before method execution (pre condition)
section.para: To enforce that all field and getter constraints are checked before a method is executed, annotate the respective method with @net.sf.oval.annotations.PreValidateObject.
In case of constraint violations a ConstraintsViolatedException is thrown and the method will not be executed.
Example usage:

section.title: Specifying method return value constraints (post condition)
section.para: By adding constraint annotations to non-void methods you can specify constraints for the return value of the given method. When the method is called and the return value does not satisfy all constraints a ConstraintsViolatedException is thrown.
Note: Despite the thrown exception the method code still has been executed, you have to manually rollback the changes performed by this method.
If the annotated method is a JavaBeans conform getter methods it's constraints will also be checked when calling the Validator.validate(Object) method on an object of this type.
Example usage:

section.title: Enforcing full object validation after constructor execution (post condition)
section.para: To enforce that all field and getter constraints are checked after an object has been instantiated, annotate the constructors of the corresponding class with @net.sf.oval.annotations.PostValidateObject.

In case of constraint violations the constructor will throw a ConstraintsViolatedException which effectively means the code trying to instantiate the object cannot get hold of a reference to the object being in an invalidate state and the invalid object will get garbage collected.
Example usage:
section.programlisting: // throws a ConstraintsViolatedException because the name field is null BusinessObject bo = new BusinessObject();

section.title: Enforcing full object validation after method execution (post condition)
section.para: To enforce that all field and getter constraints are checked after a method of an object has been executed, annotate the method with @net.sf.oval.annotations.PostValidateObject.
In case of constraint violations the method will throw an ConstraintsViolatedException.
Note: Despite the thrown exception the method code still has been executed, you have to manually rollback the changes performed by this method.
Example usage:
section.programlisting: BusinessObject bo = new BusinessObject(); bo.appendToName("123456"); // throws a ConstraintsViolatedException because field name is now too long

section.title: Getting notified about constraint violations
section.para: Alternatively to letting OVal throw ConstraintsViolatedExceptions you can configure it to notify a listener about any occuring constraint violation.

This is especially useful if you want to test input values received from the end user in the UI layer against the setter methods of a business object. You can simply pass the values to the corresponding setters and have any detected violations collect by a ConstraintsViolatedListener. Afterwards you can report all violations back to the UI layer and have them displayed to the end user.
Note: For constructor parameter constraint violations OVal always throws an exception as this is the only way of preventing the constructor being executed.

section.title: Creating custom constraints
section.para: Developing custom constraints is fairly easy. All you need to do is:

listitem.para: Create a check class that implements net.sf.oval.Check or extends net.sf.oval.AbstractCheck. The check class must be in the same package as your custom constraint annotation and must be named like your constraint with the appendix "Check".
Use the custom constraint annotation in your code.

section.title: Expressing complex class specific constraints
section.para: If you have to express a rather complex constraint that is used only in one class you might not want to create a custom constraint annotation for it. Alternatively you can implement the constraint in a method that has a single parameter to receive the value to validate and which returns true if the constraint is satisfied and false if its violated.
